text:
Maps, broadcasts, list comprehension. They can all be technically used for the same thing so which do you guys prefer to use?

I personally prefer `map` for functions, because its nice and explicit; and `broadcast` for operators because it looks nice. I rarely try and use list comprehensions.

Also on a related note, why is `broadcast` slightly faster than `map` on my PC?

text:
Maps are explicit and functorial. I think that they are really important for readability when one is transforming inherently multi-dimensional data.

When one is just working with a business-domain lists, a broadcast can be short and sweet.

Detest comprehensions. Pythonic slog alternative to a well-established functional convention.

text: I like comprehensions because they are so literal. "[x+1 for x in xs]" does exactly what it says on the tin. Map is super cool too, I usually use it with the pipe operator. Broadcasting is nice for numerical array ops, but that's a minority of what I do.
